title: N-400 Vocabulary Guide
content:
Officers often ask applicants to define these complex legal terms in "simple English" to verify they understand what they are signing, rather than just memorizing "No" answers.

Insight for Your Preparation:
The research indicates that while most applicants focus on the 100 (or 128) civics questions, the "N-400 Vocabulary" is often the "invisible barrier" where applicants freeze.

Analogy: Think of the N-400 vocabulary like the safety warning signs on a road. The Civics Test is knowing the rules of the road, but the N-400 vocabulary ensures you aren't bringing anything dangerous into the car.

title: 1. High-Risk Legal & Moral Terms
content: These terms appear in questions asking if you have ever committed crimes or participated in bad groups. Failing to define these can be a "red flag".

definition: Killing a group of people because of their race or religion
Hurting someone because of their religion, race, or political opinion
When the government has total control over everything and people have no power
No private property. The government owns everything
A group that uses violence against people and the government

title: 2. Oath and Military Terms
content: These terms appear in the final section where you promise loyalty to the U.S. You typically must answer "Yes" to these questions.

definition: A promise to be loyal to the United States
To carry a weapon to protect the country
Helping the army without fighting (like working as a cook or a doctor)
Helping the country in a major emergency (like a disaster)

title: 3. Status and Administrative Terms
content: These terms clarify your current standing and honesty.

definition: A royal title like Prince or King (you must give this up to become a citizen)
A hospital for people with mental health problems

term: Claim to be a U.S. Citizen
definition: To lie and say you are a citizen when you are not
A person who does not live in a specific place
Whether you are married, single, divorced, or widowed
